Description of the Stationary Source and Regulated Substances
Enterprise Gas Processing, LLC (Enterprise) owns and operates the Norco Fractionation Plant located in Norco, Louisiana.  The Fractionation Plant is located at 15608 Highway 61 adjacent to Motiva Enterprises LLC, an oil refinery, and Shell Chemical Company, a SOCMI chemical complex.  A location map is provided as Figure 1 in Appendix A.  The Fractionation Plant separates and recovers various components in natural gas liquids from nearby gas processing plants.  This plant produces ethane, propane, isobutane, n-butane, and natural gasoline.  The facility primarily consists of a deethanizer  (DeC2), a depropanizer (DeC3), a debutanizer (DeC4), two deisobutanizers (DIB), ethane treater, and on site storage facilities.  Process heat is provided by a closed loop hot oil system using direct fired natural gas furnaces.

The Norco Fractionation Plant was evaluated to determine if any regulated flammable or toxic material exceeds the threshold quantity set by 40 CFR 68.130.  Listed flammable substances which are stored above threshold quantities at the Norco Fractionation Plant are natural gasoline, butane, isobutane, raw make, propane, rerun propane, and heating oil.  Since natural gasoline and heating oil have NFPA ratings less than 4, these two flammable substances are exempt from the threshold determination.  Because the distance of the worst-case release of a flammable substance reaches public receptors, and the Plant is subject to OSHA PSM, the Norco Fractionation Plant is classified as a Program 3 process under the Accidental Release Program (ARP).  

Accidental Release Prevention and Response Policies
The Norco Fractionation Plant has a long-standing commitment to worker and public safety.  This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as training personnel and considering safety in the design, installation, operation and maintenance of the facility's processes.  The

Enterprise policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of substances.  However, if a release does occur, trained personnel will respond to, control, and contain the release.

Off-Site Consequence Analysis Results
Flammable Substances - Worst-Case Scenario
The endpoint for the worst-case release of a flammable substance is 1 psi overpressure (15.7 psia), resulting from a vapor cloud explosion.  The ARP Program requirement for flammables assumes an instantaneous release and vapor cloud explosion.  A yield factor of 10 percent of the available energy released in the explosion shall be used to determine the distance to the explosion endpoint.  Since the worst-case release scenario for a flammable substance is based on the assumption that the entire quantity of the substance forms a vapor cloud, passive mitigation systems are not applicable.  Isobutane, stored in the new pressurized storage sphere, is the worst-case flammable release with a 1.40-mile distance to the endpoint.  

Flammable Substances - Alternative-Case Scenario
A single alternative release scenario for all flammable substances is required under the ARP program.  One possible, more likely to occur, release scenario has been identified for the propane storage bullet (88 oF).  An overfilling of the bullet causes a release from the six-inch piping of the pressure relief valve set at 250 psi.  The release is assumed to continue for ten minutes and then ignite in a vapor cloud explosion.  The distance to the endpoint with a 1 psi over pressure for this release scenario is 0.25 miles, and the distance to the Lower Flammability Limit  (LFL) of propane in this scenario is 0.1 miles. 

Toxic Substances
The Norco Fractionation Plant does not have any toxic substances held above the threshold quantity.  Therefore, analysis of worst-case and alternative-case release scenarios for toxic substances is not required.   

General Accident Release Program
The processes at the Norco Fractionat

ion Plant are regulated by the EPA's RMP program and are also subject to the Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA's) process safety management (PSM) standard.  This section addresses the elements of the OSHA PSM requirements and describes the system in place at the Fractionation Plant to comply with the accident prevention program.

Employee Participation
Active employee participation and involvement in the development and implementation of the Fractionation Plant's PSM program is an important in minimizing or preventing releases of toxic, reactive, flammable, or explosive chemicals.  Employee involvement helps to insure that all perspectives regarding PSM are considered, and the best ideas are implemented.  Open communications regarding all health and safety issues are encouraged between supervisors and employees. 

The Fractionation Plant promotes employee involvement in safety issues through these programs; Health Safety & Environmental Team, regularly scheduled safety meetings, tail-gate safety meetings, Hazard Communication, Safety Suggestion Forms, near-miss reporting, and special training programs (emergency response, first aid).  Employee involvement is critical in the development and conduct of all accident prevention activities and in active safety programs.  Accident prevention is discussed at the regularly scheduled safety meetings, and employees are encouraged to discuss accident prevention with their supervisors if they have questions, comments, or suggestions.

Process Safety Information (PSI)
Complete and accurate written process safety information concerning process chemicals, process technology, and process equipment is essential to an effective PSM and RMP programs.  Process safety information is readily available to all employees.

The Fractionation Plant keeps a variety of technical documents that are used to help maintain safe operation of the processes.  These documents address chemical properties and associated hazards, limit

s for key process parameters and specific chemical inventories, and equipment design basis/configuration information.  Chemical specific information is provided in material safety data sheets (MSDS), which are kept on the Enterprise Intranet.  MSDS include information on exposure hazards and limits, and exposure response/treatment for specific chemicals.  Technical documents about the design and construction of process equipment include information on materials of construction, design pressure and temperature ratings, and electrical rating of equipment.

Process Hazard Analysis (PHA)
The Fractionation Plant has a comprehensive program to help ensure that hazards associated with the various processes are identified and controlled.  Within this program, each process has been systematically examined to identify hazards and ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage these hazards.  

Two main methods used to perform the PHA are hazard and operability and the what-if/checklist method analysis.  These analyses are conducted using people with operating and maintenance experience as well as engineering expertise.  The goal is to identify and evaluate hazards of the process as well as accident prevention and mitigation measures, and then make final suggestions for additional prevention and/or mitigation measures where they are determined to be necessary.

PHA findings are forwarded to local and corporate management for resolution.  Implementation of mitigation options in response to the findings are based on a relative risk ranking assigned in the PHA analysis.  These rankings help to ensure that the potential accident scenarios assigned the highest risk receive immediate attention.  All approved mitigation options in response to PHA team findings are tracked until completion, when final resolutions are documented and retained.  

To help ensure that the process controls and/or process hazards do not eventually deviate significantly from the original design safety

features, the plant periodically updates and revalidates the hazard analysis results.  The periodic reviews are conducted at least every 5 years while the process is in operation.  The results and findings are forwarded to management for consideration, and the results and findings are documented and retained.  These analyses are also subject to amendment, if necessary, within the facility Management of Change program. 

Operating Procedures
The Fractionation Plant maintains written procedures that address various modes of process operations such as; startup, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, normal shutdown, and initial startup of a new process.  These procedures provide guidance for experienced operators and for training new operators.  Operating procedures are periodically reviewed and annually certified as current and accurate.  The review and certification involves operators and technical staff.

The intent of the operating procedures is to provide workable, useful, and clearly written instructions for conducting operating activities.  To have effective operating procedures, the task and procedures directly and indirectly related to the covered process, must be appropriate, clear, consistent, and communicated to employees.  Operating procedures are specific instructions or details on what steps are taken or followed in carrying out the stated procedures.  The specific instructions include the applicable safety precautions and appropriate information on safety implications.

Pre-startup Safety Review (PSSR)
The Fractionation Plant conducts a PSSR on any new facility of facility modification that requires a change in process safety information.  The purpose of the PSSR is to ensure those safety features, procedures, personnel, and equipment are appropriately prepared for startup prior to placing the equipment into service.  This review provides one additional check to make sure construction is in accordance with design specifications and

that all supporting systems are operational.  The PSSR involves field verification of the construction and serves a quality assurance function by requiring verification that accident prevention program requirements are properly implemented.

Training
In addition to training on operating procedures, the Fractionation Plant has a comprehensive training program for all employees involved in the operating process. New employees receive basic training in gas plant operations.  In addition all operators receive refresher training on the operating procedures to ensure that their skills and knowledge are maintained. All training is documented for each operator including the means to verify that the operator understood the training.

Contractors
Contractors are used during periods of increased maintenance or construction activities. Since some contractors work on or near process equipment, the Fractionation Plant has procedures in place to ensure that contractors perform their work in a safe manner. These procedures require contractors have appropriate knowledge and skills, are aware of the hazards of their workplace, understand what to do in case of an emergency, understand and follow specific safety rules, and inform plant personnel of hazards found during their work.  This is accomplished by providing contractors with an orientation that includes; process overview, information about safety and health hazards, emergency response plan requirements, and safe work practices before beginning their work.  The Fractionation Plant also evaluates contractor safety programs and personnel periodically monitor contractor performance to ensure compliance with safety obligations.

Mechanical Integrity
The Fractionation Plant has well established practices and procedures for maintaining process equipment.  The basic aspects of this program include; training, written procedures, performing inspections and tests, correcting equipment deficiencies, and applying quality assurance measures.

Baseline and periodic inspection data on all equipment and systems is maintained and utilized to assure continued serviceability, function, and safety.

Maintenance personnel receive training which include an overview of the process, safety and health hazards, applicable maintenance procedures, emergency response plans, specialized training for specific equipment, and applicable safe work practices.  

The Fractionation Plant incorporates quality assurance measures into equipment purchases and repairs to ensure that the new equipment is suitable for its intended use and that proper materials and spare parts are used when repairs are made.

Safe Work Practices
The Fractionation Plant has long standing safe work practices in place to help ensure worker and process safety.  Safe work practices include control of the entry/presence/exit of support personnel, lockout/tagout procedures, procedures for safe removal of hazardous substances before process equipment and piping is opened, hot work permits, and permit and procedures for confined space entry.  These procedures along with training of affected personnel help to ensure that operations and maintenance activities are performed safely.

Management of Change
The Fractionation Plant has a comprehensive system to manage changes to all covered processes.  This system requires that changes to items such as process equipment, technology, procedures, and other facility changes be properly reviewed and authorized before being implemented.  Changes are reviewed to ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage any new hazards and to verify that existing controls have not been compromised by the change. Affected chemical hazard information, process, operating limits, and equipment information, as well as procedures are updated to incorporate these changes.  Operating and maintenance personnel are provided any necessary training on the change.   

Incident Investigation
The Fractionation Plant promptly investigates all in

cidents that resulted in or reasonably could have resulted in, a fire/explosion, toxic gas release, major property damage, environmental loss, or personal injury.  The goal of each investigation is to gather the facts, determine the root cause, and develop corrective action to prevent the reoccurrence of the incident or a similar event.  

Compliance Audits
To help ensure that the accident prevention plan is functioning properly, the Fractionation Plant periodically conducts an audit to determine if the procedures and practices required by the accident prevention program are being implemented.  Both hourly and staff personnel participate as audit team members.  The audit team develops findings that are forwarded to plant management for resolution.  Corrective actions taken in response to the audit team's findings are tracked until complete.  The final resolution of each finding is documented and recent audit reports are retained.

Chemical Specific Prevention Steps
The processes at the Fractionation Plant have hazards that must be managed to ensure safe operation.  The following is a description of existing safety features applicable to prevention of accidental releases of regulated substances in the facility.  

Universal Prevention Activities
The accident prevention program is applied to all RMP covered processes at the Fractionation Plant.  These prevention programs activities help prevent potential accident scenarios that could be caused by equipment failures or human errors.

Specialized Safety Features
The Fractionation Plant has safety features on many units to help contain/control a release, quickly detect a release, and reduce the consequences of a release.  

Release Detection
1. Hydrocarbon detectors with alarms

Release Containment/Control
1. Process relief valves that discharge to a flare to capture and incinerate episodic releases
2. Valves to permit isolation of the process (manual or automated) 
3. Automated shutdown systems for specific process para

meters 
4. Curbing or diking to contain liquid releases
5. Redundant equipment and instrumentation
6. Atmospheric relief devices

Release Mitigation
1. Fire suppression and extinguishing systems
2. Deluge system for specific equipment
3. Trained in emergency procedures
4. Personal protective equipment

Five Year Accident History
The Enterprise Norco Fractionation Plant has an excellent record of accident prevention.  Over the past 5 years there have been no accidental releases from this facility. A program is in place for investigation, evaluation, and documentation of any accidents that might occur in the future.

Emergency Response Program Information
The Fractionation Plant maintains a written emergency response program, which is in place to protect worker and public safety as well as the environment.  The program consists of procedures for responding to a release of a regulated substance, including the possibility of a fire or explosion if a flammable substance is accidentally released.  The procedures address all aspects of emergency response, including proper first aid and medical treatment for exposures, evacuation plans and accounting for personnel after an evacuation, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public, and cleanup/decontamination requirements should a release occur.  Also, the facility has procedures that address maintenance, inspection, and testing of emergency response equipment.  Employees receive training in these procedures as necessary to perform their specific emergency response duties.  The emergency response program is updated when necessary, based on modifications made to the facility.
